paragraphs.zh-tw: 身為利馬的小男孩，爺爺曾告訴我西班牙人征服秘魯的傳說。印加國王阿塔瓦爾帕，被俘虜並遭到殺害。
paragraphs.en: As a boy in Lima, my grandfather told me a legend of the Spanish conquest of Peru. Atahualpa, emperor of the Inca,had been captured and killed.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 皮澤洛和他帶領的征服者得到財富。他們的事蹟與榮耀傳回西班牙，吸引一波波渴望黃金和榮譽的西班牙人。他們湧到城鎮問印加人：「哪裡還有我們能征服的文明？哪裡還有更多的黃金？」於是印加人出於報復，告訴他們：「去亞馬遜吧。
paragraphs.en: Pizarro and his conquistadorshad grown rich, and tales of their conquestand glory had reached Spain and was bringing new waves of Spaniards,hungry for gold and glory. They would go into towns and ask the Inca, "Where's another civilizationwe can conquer? Where's more gold?" And the Inca, out of vengeance, told them, "Go to the Amazon.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 你會找到你想要的黃金。那裡有一個叫帕蒂蒂的城市，西班牙語叫做 El Dorado，完全是由黃金打造而成。」西班牙人於是出發前往叢林，但只有幾個人回來，他們帶回了許多故事。傳說那裡有強大的薩滿巫師，手持毒箭的戰士，樹林高聳成蔭，蔽不見日，有吃鳥的蜘蛛，可以吞掉一整個人的蛇，和一條沸騰的河流。
paragraphs.en: You'll find all the gold you want there. In fact, there is a city called Paititi --El Dorado in Spanish -- made entirely of gold." The Spanish set off into the jungle, but the few that returncome back with stories, stories of powerful shamans, of warriors with poisoned arrows, of trees so tall they blotted out the sun, spiders that ate birds,snakes that swallowed men whole and a river that boiled.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這些故事，成為我的童年回憶。時光流逝，
paragraphs.en: All this became a childhood memory. And years passed.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 現在我在南衛理公會大學攻讀博士學位，試著了解秘魯的地熱潛能。我記起這個傳說，開始思考這個問題：那沸騰的河流真的存在嗎？我問過很多大學的同行、政府部門、石油、天然氣及煤礦公司，答案一致是否定的。
paragraphs.en: I'm working on my PhD at SMU, trying to understandPeru's geothermal energy potential, when I remember this legend, and I began asking that question. Could the boiling river exist? I asked colleagues from universities, the government, oil, gas and mining companies, and the answer was a unanimous no.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這言之有理。你知道，世界上確實有沸騰的河流，但通常跟火山有關。
paragraphs.en: And this makes sense. You see, boiling riversdo exist in the world, but they're generallyassociated with volcanoes.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 只有強勁的熱力源頭才能產生這麼大的地熱現象。你們可以看到這些紅點代表火山。亞馬遜流域沒有火山，而大部分的秘魯地區也沒有。
paragraphs.en: You need a powerful heat source to produce such a largegeothermal manifestation. And as you can see from the red dotshere, which are volcanoes, we don't have volcanoes in the Amazon, nor in most of Peru.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 由此看來，我們不可能見到一條沸騰的河流。一次家庭聚餐，我提到這個故事，我的姑姑告訴我：「但是安德烈，我以前去過那裡，還在河裡游泳過。」這時叔叔插嘴說：
paragraphs.en: So it follows: We should not expectto see a boiling river. Telling this same storyat a family dinner, my aunt tells me, "But no, Andrés, I've been there.I've swum in that river." Then my uncle jumps in.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 「安德烈，她不是在開玩笑。你要知道只有在豪雨之後，你才能在這條河裡游泳。有一位強大的薩滿保䕶著這條河。
paragraphs.en: "No, Andrés, she's not kidding. You see, you can only swim in itafter a very heavy rain, and it's protected by a powerful shaman.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 你的姑姑就是他妻子的友人。」"¿Cómo?" （蛤？）儘管我對此的科學根據存疑，我發現自己跟著姑姑的指引，深入叢林，而最近的火山中心遠在 700 公里之外。坦白說，我有心理準備，看到傳說中的「亞馬遜暖水流」。但是隨即，我聽到一些聲音。初時一陣低湧，後來我們走近時聲音越來越大。
paragraphs.en: Your aunt, she's friends with his wife." "¿Cómo?" ["Huh?"] You know, despite allmy scientific skepticism, I found myself hiking into the jungle,guided by my aunt, over 700 kilometers awayfrom the nearest volcanic center, and well, honestly,mentally preparing myself to behold the legendary"warm stream of the Amazon." But then ... I heard something, a low surge that got louder and louder as we came closer.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 好像海浪持續打在岸上。我們接近時，煙霧與水汽穿過樹林而來。接著我看見了這個。
paragraphs.en: It sounded like ocean wavesconstantly crashing, and as we got closer, I saw smoke, vapor,coming up through the trees. And then, I saw this.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我立刻拿出溫度計，當時河的平均溫度是攝氏 86 度。還不到沸點的攝氏 100 度，但絕對夠接近了。
paragraphs.en: I immediately grabbed for my thermometer, and the average temperatures in the river were 86 degrees C. This is not quitethe 100-degree C boiling but definitely close enough.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這條河流又燙又湍急，薩滿的學徒帶我順著河往上游前行，到了河流最神聖的地方。
paragraphs.en: The river flowed hot and fast. I followed it upriver and was led by,actually, the shaman's apprentice to the most sacred site on the river.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 超乎尋常的是，源頭的水流是冷的，直到這個地點，傳說中蛇神 (Yacumama) 之家，這條巨蛇之靈是所有水流之母，孕育了熱水和冷水。
paragraphs.en: And this is what's bizarre -- It starts off as a cold stream. And here, at this site, is the home of the Yacumama, mother of the waters,a giant serpent spirit who births hot and cold water.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 在這裡，我們發現了一道混合著冷水流的溫泉，就在巨蛇母親保護著的下頜。就像是傳說成真。到了第二天早上，我一覺醒來…我想要一杯茶，
paragraphs.en: And here we find a hot spring, mixing with cold stream waterunderneath her protective motherly jaws and thus bringing their legends to life. The next morning, I woke up and -- I asked for tea.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 有人給我一個馬克杯和茶包，然後指著那條河。讓我感到意外的是，河水很乾淨，有很好的味道，這對於地熱系統來說不太尋常。
paragraphs.en: I was handed a mug, a tea bag and, well, pointed towards the river. To my surprise, the water was cleanand had a pleasant taste, which is a little weirdfor geothermal systems.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 神奇的是，當地人一直都知道這地方，而我肯定不是第一個知道的外人。這不過是他們生活的一部分，
paragraphs.en: What was amazing is that the locals had alwaysknown about this place, and that I was by no meansthe first outsider to see it. It was just part of their everyday life.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 喝河流的水、吸入那
paragraphs.en: They drink its water. They take in its vapor.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 利用河水煮食、清潔洗淨，甚至用它來製藥。我和那位薩滿見面，他像是這條河流與這片樹林的一部分。
paragraphs.en: They cook with it, clean with it, even make their medicines with it. I met the shaman, and he seemed like an extensionof the river and his jungle.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 他問我為何而來，並且仔細聽我回答。然後，讓我如釋重負的是──坦白說，我原本非常緊張──一抹微笑像蛇爬過他的面孔，然後他笑了。
paragraphs.en: He asked for my intentions and listened carefully. Then, to my tremendous relief -- I was freaking out,to be honest with you -- a smile began to snake across his face,and he just laughed.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我得到薩滿的祝福來硏究這條河，只要我取得的河水樣本在實驗室分析過後，無論我在世界哪裡，都要把水再灑回到地上，薩滿說，這樣河水才能找到回家的路。自從 2011 年第一次探訪以來，我每年都回去。實地考察令人振奮，過程艱辛，有時甚至危險。
paragraphs.en: I had received the shaman's blessingto study the river, on the condition that after I takethe water samples and analyze them in my lab, wherever I was in the world, that I pour the watersback into the ground so that, as the shaman said, the waters could find their way back home. I've been back every yearsince that first visit in 2011, and the fieldwork has been exhilarating, demanding and at times dangerous.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 國家地理雜誌曾為其中一個故事做過專題，當時我被一塊紙張大小的石頭卡住了，身上只穿著沙灘褲和涼鞋。我那時身處在攝氏 80 度的河流和一道溫泉之間，就像這樣，接近沸騰。
paragraphs.en: One story was even featuredin National Geographic Magazine. I was trapped on a small rockabout the size of a sheet of paper in sandals and board shorts, in between an 80 degree C river and a hot spring that, well,looked like this, close to boiling.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 在這之上的是亞馬遜雨林，滂沱大雨，伸手不見五指。
paragraphs.en: And on top of that,it was Amazon rain forest. Pshh, pouring rain, couldn't see a thing.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 溫差讓周圍變得白濛濛，簡直是雪盲。真令人緊張。
paragraphs.en: The temperature differentialmade it all white. It was a whiteout. Intense.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 如今，經過多年的考察，不久我會發表相關的地球物理與化學硏究成果。今天我想在 TED 的講臺上與你們分享，我第一次公開的部分發現。
paragraphs.en: Now, after years of work, I'll soon be submitting my geophysicaland geochemical studies for publication. And I'd like to share, today,with all of you here, on the TED stage, for the first time,some of these discoveries.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 首先，這些故事不是傳說。想不到吧！最初我進行研究時，衛星影像的解析度非常低，根本幫不上忙，
paragraphs.en: Well, first off, it's not a legend. Surprise! When I first started the research, the satellite imagery was toolow-resolution to be meaningful.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 可以說是沒有地圖可言。多謝 Google 地球團隊，我現在有了這樣的畫面。
paragraphs.en: There were just no good maps. Thanks to the supportof the Google Earth team, I now have this.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 此外，河流之名Shanay-timpishka 的原意是「以太陽之熱沸騰」，顯然我並非第一個好奇河水為何沸騰的人，也顯示人類向來在想辦法解釋我們身處的世界。所以，那條河是怎麼沸騰的？（水沸騰聲）其實我花了三年才得到這段影片。
paragraphs.en: Not only that, the indigenous nameof the river, Shanay-timpishka, "boiled with the heat of the sun," indicating that I'm not the firstto wonder why the river boils, and showing that humanityhas always sought to explain the world around us. So why does the river boil? (Bubbling sounds) It actually took me three yearsto get that footage.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 地殼裂縫的溫泉，就如我們身體同樣地，地球也有熱流穿過它的裂縫和斷層。
paragraphs.en: Fault-fed hot springs. As we have hot blood runningthrough our veins and arteries, so, too, the earth has hot waterrunning through its cracks and faults.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 當動脈接近地殼，這些大地的動脈，會展現地熱的特質：火山噴氣孔、溫泉，以及我們看到的，沸騰的河流。真正驚人的地方，是這裡的範圍有多大。
paragraphs.en: Where these arteries come to the surface,these earth arteries, we'll get geothermal manifestations: fumaroles, hot springsand in our case, the boiling river. What's truly incredible, though,is the scale of this place.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 下次過馬路時，你可以想想看。這條河多數的流域寬度超過兩線道。
paragraphs.en: Next time you cross the road,think about this. The river flows wider than a two-lane road along most of its path.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 長達 6.24 公里都是滾燙的水。真令人敬畏。
paragraphs.en: It flows hot for 6.24 kilometers. Truly impressive.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 那裡有比這個 TED 講臺還大的熱水池，你現在看到的瀑布，有六公尺高，而且全部都是接近沸騰的河水。我們記錄了河水各處的溫度，這是實地考察最難的部分。
paragraphs.en: There are thermal poolslarger than this TED stage, and that waterfall that you see there is six meters tall -- and all with near-boiling water. We mapped the temperaturesalong the river, and this was by far the mostdemanding part of the fieldwork.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我們得到的結果實在太棒了。對不起，我的地球科學家本性又來了。
paragraphs.en: And the results were just awesome. Sorry -- the geoscientistin me coming out.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 結果顯示很驚人的變化。你看河水最先是冷的，
paragraphs.en: And it showed this amazing trend. You see, the river starts off cold.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 接著加熱、冷卻、再加熱、再冷卻，再加熱，產生這個漂亮的衰減曲線，直到它匯流進冷水河裡。我了解不是每個人都是地熱學家，所以用一般的說法形容：每個人都喜歡咖啡，
paragraphs.en: It then heats up, cools back down,heats up, cools back down, heats up again, and then hasthis beautiful decay curve until it smashes into this cold river. Now, I understand not all of youare geothermal scientists, so to put it in more everyday terms: Everyone loves coffee.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 是吧？很好。通常一杯咖啡的溫度是攝氏 54 度。熱一點的是 60 度。
paragraphs.en: Yes? Good. Your regular cup of coffee, 54 degrees C, an extra-hot one, well, 60.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 所以用咖啡店的說法，沸水河的圖示，像是這樣。這裡你得到一杯熱咖啡，
paragraphs.en: So, put in coffee shop terms, the boiling river plots like this. There you have your hot coffee.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 這裡你得到一杯很燙的咖啡，你可以看到在某些區段河流比很燙的咖啡還燙。這些是平均水溫。
paragraphs.en: Here you have your extra-hot coffee, and you can seethat there's a bit point there where the river is still hotterthan even the extra-hot coffee. And these are average water temperatures.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我們在旱季做測量，以確保貼近地熱的溫度。另外有一個魔法數字，還沒有提到。這數字是是攝氏 47 度。高過這個溫度，有受傷的危險。我從親身的經歷學到這一點。
paragraphs.en: We took these in the dry season to ensurethe purest geothermal temperatures. But there's a magic number herethat's not being shown, and that number is 47 degrees C, because that's where things start to hurt, and I know this from verypersonal experience.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 超過這個溫度，你不會想要進到河裡去。你要非常小心，
paragraphs.en: Above that temperature,you don't want to get in that water. You need to be careful.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 有可能會致命。我看過各式各樣的動物掉進去，讓我驚訝的是，牠們被煮熟的過程都差不多。
paragraphs.en: It can be deadly. I've seen all sorts of animals fall in, and what's shocking to me,is the process is pretty much the same.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 當牠們掉入熱水後，第一個變化的是眼睛。顯然，眼睛很容易熟，馬上就變成乳白色。
paragraphs.en: So they fall in and the first thingto go are the eyes. Eyes, apparently, cook very quickly.They turn this milky-white color.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 流水承載著牠們，動物試圖要游出來，但高溫切骨，實在太燙了。
paragraphs.en: The stream is carrying them. They're trying to swim out,but their meat is cooking on the bone because it's so hot.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 所以牠們漸漸失去動力，漸漸失去動力，直到熱水淹進嘴巴，牠們就從裡到外被煮熟了。我們都有點虐待傾向，是吧？天啊。
paragraphs.en: So they're losing power, losing power, until finally they get to a pointwhere hot water goes into their mouths and they cook from the inside out. A bit sadistic, aren't we? Jeez.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 把這些先放一邊。回到這個，驚人的高溫，
paragraphs.en: Leave them marinating for a little longer. What's, again, amazingare these temperatures.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 類似的情況在世界各處的火山都可見到，甚至是黃石公園這樣的超級火山。但特別的地方是：這些資料顯示，這條沸水河的存在獨立於火山活動。
paragraphs.en: They're similar to things that I've seenon volcanoes all over the world and even super-volcanoes like Yellowstone. But here's the thing: the data is showingthat the boiling river exists independent of volcanism.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 它的起源既不是岩漿，也不是火山，它離最近的火山可是有 700 公里遠。怎麼會有這樣的一條沸水河存在呢？過去幾年來，我問過地熱和火山專家，仍無法在另一個非火山的地熱系統裡，找到同樣等級的系統。
paragraphs.en: It's neither magmaticor volcanic in origin, and again, over 700 kilometers awayfrom the nearest volcanic center. How can a boiling river exist like this? I've asked geothermal expertsand volcanologists for years, and I'm still unable to find anothernon-volcanic geothermal system of this magnitude.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 它獨一無二，是世界級的特別。
paragraphs.en: It's unique. It's special on a global scale.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 那麼，這是怎麼發生的？熱能從哪裡來？我們的研究還沒有結束，尚待進一步釐清問題，了解這個系統。但從目前的資料來看，看起來這是由一個廣大的熱液系統所造成。簡單來說，越深入地心，溫度就越燙。
paragraphs.en: So, still -- how does it work? Where do we get this heat? There's still more research to be done to better constrain the problemand better understand the system, but from what the data is telling us now, it looks to be the resultof a large hydrothermal system. Basically, it works like this: So, the deeper you gointo the earth, the hotter it gets.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我們把這種現象稱為地溫梯度。水流可能來自遙遠的安第斯山脈冰川，再往下滲透深入到地球回到地表形成這條沸水河，熱力來自地溫梯度，一切源於這種獨特的地質背景。
paragraphs.en: We refer to thisas the geothermal gradient. The waters could be comingfrom as far away as glaciers in the Andes, then seeping down deep into the earth and coming out to form the boiling river after getting heated upfrom the geothermal gradient, all due to this unique geologic setting.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 在河中，以及其週邊，我們有一些發現。透過許多夥伴的努力，包括國家地理雜誌的韋爾斯博士，和加州大學戴維斯分校的喬恩·艾森博士。我們將各種嗜極端生物做基因體定序，這些生物生長在河流的四周，我們也發現新生物，是住在沸水河的獨特物種。但同樣的，這所有研究、發現，和傳說的背後，仍留下一個問題：沸騰河流為什麼重要？這片常年雲霧繚繞，隱蔽在叢林深處的一方寸土，為什麼重要？一個兒時傳說的細節，為什麼重要？對薩滿和他的村落而言，這是一塊聖地；
paragraphs.en: Now, we foundthat in and around the river -- this is working with colleagues from National Geographic,Dr. Spencer Wells, and Dr. Jon Eisen from UC Davis -- we genetically sequencedthe extremophile lifeforms living in and around the river,and have found new lifeforms, unique species livingin the boiling river. But again, despite all of these studies,all of these discoveries and the legends, a question remains: What is the significanceof the boiling river? What is the significanceof this stationary cloud that always hoversover this patch of jungle? And what is the significance of a detail in a childhood legend? To the shaman and his community,it's a sacred site.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 對我，一個地質學家而言，這是獨一無二的地熱現象；但對非法伐木者和養牛戶而言，這僅是另一個可剝削的資源。
paragraphs.en: To me, as a geoscientist, it's a unique geothermal phenomenon. But to the illegal loggersand cattle farmers, it's just another resource to exploit.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 對秘魯政府，它只是另一個未經保護的土地，等著被開發。我的目標是確保無論誰控制了這塊土地，都能了解沸騰河流的獨特性與重要性。
paragraphs.en: And to the Peruvian government,it's just another stretch of unprotected land ready for development. My goal is to ensurethat whoever controls this land understands the boiling river'suniqueness and significance.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 因為，那就是我們討論關於重要性的提問。對於世間萬物，我們定義了事物的重要性，
paragraphs.en: Because that's the question, one of significance. And the thing there is, we define significance.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 那是我們，我們有這個力量，我們是做出決定的那群人，決定事物是神聖亦或微不足道。
paragraphs.en: It's us. We have that power. We are the ones who draw that line between the sacred and the trivial.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 在這個時代，看似萬物都已被組織、測量，以及研究過了。在這個資訊的時代，我想提醒各位，所謂的探索，不只發生在黑暗虛無的未知當中，也發生在生活的嘈雜與鋪天蓋地的資料中。世上還有很多待發掘的事物。
paragraphs.en: And in this age, where everything seems mapped,measured and studied, in this age of information, I remind you all that discoveriesare not just made in the black void of the unknown but in the white noiseof overwhelming data. There remains so much to explore.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 我們住在一個不可思議的世界。所以出走吧！
paragraphs.en: We live in an incredible world. So go out.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 抱著好奇心。因為我們生活的這個世界，薩滿們仍為叢林裡的神靈唱歌，那裡真的有沸騰的河流，那裡的傳說會走進真實人生。
paragraphs.en: Be curious. Because we do live in a world where shamans still singto the spirits of the jungle, where rivers do boil and where legends do come to life.

paragraphs.zh-tw: 謝謝各位。
paragraphs.en: Thank you very much.

title: Andres Ruzo The Mythical Boiling River Of The Amazon
